results.title: Earthware
results.creator_credit: Donald Winkler, Richard Raxlen, Colin Low, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This short impressionistic film takes us to Nigeria, Japan, Mexico where craftsmen work clay to produce ritual vessels and everyday objects. Film without words.

results.title: Our changing earth. Part 1. The Earth's rocky crust
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and Harvard Film Service, Harvard University
results.brief_description: Physiography is presented as a dynamic process: the forces which have shaped the earth as it is today are still at work changing it further. The part played by the water cycle in determining the physiography of the earth is emphasised, and the formation of igneous, sedimentary, and metamorphic rocks is illustrated by models and by animated diagrams.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and Harvard Film Service, Harvard University

results.title: Earthquakes and volcanoes
results.brief_description: The forces that cause earthquakes and volcanoes. Wherever the earth has been folded up into mountains, cracks may appear in the crust. When blocks of earth move along these cracks, or faults, earthquakes may occur. If melted rock is near a fault or weak spot in the crust, it may be forced out to produce a volcanic eruption.

results.title: Changes in its surface
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Earth”.
Uses the illustration of an erupting volcano to show that the surface of the earth is changing. Explains and demonstrates other forces both internal and external that are changing the earth’s surface.

results.title: Earth satellites: explorers of outer space
results.brief_description: Scenes at the Army and Navy launching site show satellites being built, prepared for launching and taking off. Uses animated drawings to explain why satellites stay in orbit, how orbits may vary, and how information is received from satellites. Includes a sequence describing things to come in the space age.

results.title: The Earth reveals
results.creator_credit: Ian Dunlop, Eric Thompson and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Mineral mining in Australia and the never-ending search for new resources: gold at Kalgoorlie; lead, zinc and silver at Broken Hill and the floatation process used; mining at Iron Knob in South Australia; copper and lead at Mt Isa; uranium at Mary Kathleen; and search for oil in Queensland and New Guinea.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ian Dunlop, Eric Thompson and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit

results.title: Earth is a battlefield
results.creator_credit: Dick Taylor, Geoffrey Sumner and W.M. Larkins Studio
results.brief_description: A light-hearted history of the contribution steel has made to world food supplies and the importance of exports made from steel in paying for imported food. Original animation techniques, with a good musical score and a commentary of rhyming couplets make for a delightful and useful film. Animation by Beryl Stevens and others

results.title: The Earth in motion
results.creator_credit: Walter Bartky and ERPI Classroom Films
results.brief_description: Deals with the dynamic aspects of the earth as a planet. Demonstrates: 1. Sphericity. - 2. Axis rotation established by star trails and the Foucault pendulum. - 3. Revolution around the sun by the motion of the sun in respect of the stars and by the annual parallax of the stars.

results.title: Talk (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Doug Wilcox, Roger Owen and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Early years at school”
Stresses the importance of talking as a medium of communication for children aged three to nine years regardless of whether or not it takes the standard middle-class form.
Suitable for teacher/tertiary levels.

group_siblings.title: Reading for what? (TEFC)
group_siblings.creator_credit: David Allen and British Broadcasting Corporation

results.title: Reading for what? (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: David Allen and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Early years at school”.
Deals analytically with areas of importance and concern to teachers of children aged three to nine. Examines the question of why most children learn to read but do not always read for pleasure or purpose.
